Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS: Phylogenetic and Taxonomic Revision of Chytridiales (Chytridiomycota)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chytridiales (=chytrids) are zoosporic fungi comprising over 320 species. As parasites of algae and decomposers of pollen, cellulose, chitin and keratin in soil and aquatic ecosystems, chytrids are environmentally important, impacting primary productivity and serving as critical links in food webs. Despite their ecological significance, patterns of biodiversity and the evolutionary history of chytrids are poorly known. In this project, chytrids will be collected and cultured from diverse habitats in southeastern and gulf coast US states, with an emphasis on algal parasites. Phylogenetic analyses of phenotypic structures, as well as multiple gene sequences, will be used to identify isolates and to conduct phylogenetic analyses. Newly discovered species will be described and monographed.

Taxonomic summaries, with interactive keys and illustrations, will be posted on a web site and published in journals, making these data openly accessible. Many new cultures will be made available to other researchers. A post-doctoral researcher will be trained, filling the void of chytrid specialists, and graduate and undergraduate students will learn modern techniques in systematics and the study of biodiversity. Program participants will present workshops to Alabama Science in Motion high school teachers and will contribute species pages to the Encyclopedia of Life, expanding knowledge of chytrids to a global community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The order Chytridiales (Chytridiomycota, chytrids) is a group of primitive, microscopic fungi that reproduce with unwalled, motile cells called zoospores. Because zoospores need water to move and not become dehydrated, chytrids grow in aquatic and moist habitats where they decompose material left by other organisms, including cellulose, pollen, chitin and keratin. In addition to being players in nature’s recycling of nutrients, chytrids are also parasites of simple aquatic organisms such as algae where they can impact food webs and the biological productivity of aquatic resources. Thus, we have explored a range of habitats to discover and describe new Chytridiales, which in the long-term will assist in defining ecological functional roles of chytrid diversity.

Molecular phylogenetic studies showed that Chytridiales was polyphyletic and the order needed revision. As the first step in revising Chytridiales, we combined analyses of DNA base sequences in genes with ultrastrastructural characters of zoospores detected with the transmission electron microscope to understand relationships and define the taxonomic boundaries of Chytridiales. As a second step based on the limits of Chytridiales, we described new taxa and transferred other misplaced members to newly erected orders. Results supported the hypothesis that ultrastructural character analysis of zoospores predicts molecular-based phylogenetic placement. Five zoospore ultrastructural characters were identified that resolved ancestral character states for Chytridiales; and a sixth character (the presence of a paracrystalline inclusion) was like a diagnostic fingerprint for the Chytridiales because it was not found in zoospores of other chytrid orders. This outcome was important because use of constallations of ultrastructural characters which were phylogenetically informative gave us a powerful tool to assist in taxonomic placement of chytrids as new configurations of zoospores were uncovered.  When the project started the Chytridiales included two configurations of zoospores. We expanded that number to eight configurations, each representing a monophyletic lineage and taxonomic unit. For example, the newly described Delfinachytrium mesopotamicum and Pseudorhizidium endosporangiatum each exhibited new zoospore configurations.

Increasing our knowledge of chytrid diversity, new members of Chytridiales have been discovered and described, some from new habitats for chytrids. As examples, from rainforest tree canopy in Australia, Dendrochytridium crassum was discovered and described. Because of the role of water in dispersal of zoospores for reproduction, how dispersal occurs to or within tree canopies remains an intriguing question. From a vernal pool in Alabama, Fayochytriomyces spinosus was collected and described. Vernal pools are known as a diverse habitat for amphibians, but had not been sampled extensively for chytrid diversity. Environmental molecular analyses of vernal pools revealed that the habitat was diverse in Chytridiales. From a freshwater lake, we recently described a new genus of Chytridiales parasitic on Dinoflagellates. Only a few chytrids have been characterized as parasites of Dinoflagellates, organisms important in aquatic food webs. We also discovered three new genera from aquatic habitats in Argentina, extending the geographical range of our survey for Chytridiales. When we used molecular methods to detect the presence of chytrid genes in nature, we found that chytrids were more diverse than our previous understanding of them based on culture and microscopic observations, and we are now revealing these chytrids using ultrastructural and molecular methods.
